title: Lead solubility prediction using shiny
description: An R package and shiny app for PHREEQC-based equilibrium lead and copper solubility prediction.
contents:
Recently, I’ve been experimenting with the excellent R package tidyphreeqc (Dunnington 2019), which provides a convenient interface for generating PHREEQC input files (Charlton and Parkhurst 2011; Parkhurst and Appelo 2013). I’ve used it to build a separate package (pbcusol (Trueman 2021)) that handles lead and copper solubility prediction specifically, with curated thermodynamic data and some domain specific features implemented in what is hopefully a straightforward collection of functions.
I’ve also implemented it in a shiny app:



Charlton, S. R., and D. L. Parkhurst. 2011. “Modules Based on the Geochemical Model Phreeqc for Use in Scripting and Programming Languages.” Computers & Geosciences 37: 1653–63. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cageo.2011.02.005.


Dunnington, Dewey. 2019. Tidyphreeqc: Tidy Geochemical Modeling Using Phreeqc. https://github.com/paleolimbot/tidyphreeqc.


Parkhurst, D. L., and C. A. J. Appelo. 2013. Description of Input and Examples for Phreeqc Version 3–a Computer Program for Speciation, Batch-Reaction, One-Dimensional Transport, and Inverse Geochemical Calculations. Vol. book 6. Techniques and Methods. U.S. Geological Survey. https://pubs.usgs.gov/tm/06/a43.


Trueman, Benjamin. 2021. Pbcusol: Predict Lead and Copper Solubility. https://github.com/bentrueman/pbcusol.
